questions.question: A 35-year-old woman presents to the clinic with sudden hives, facial swelling, and difficulty breathing shortly after eating shrimp at a restaurant. She reports similar reactions in the past. She appears anxious, with pronounced facial swelling and wheezing. Which sequence correctly describes the immunological events in this type of reaction? → Mast cell activation → IgE production → Th2 cell activation → Release of inflammatory mediators → Allergen exposure → IgE production → Mast cell activation → Release of inflammatory mediators → Th2 cell activation → IgE production → Mast cell activation → Release of inflammatory mediators → Th2 cell activation → Mast cell activation → IgE production → Release of inflammatory mediators
questions.explanation: → Th2 cell activation → IgE production → Mast cell activation → Release of inflammatory mediators Correct Answer: C) Allergen exposure → Th2 cell activation → IgE production → Mast cell activation → Release of inflammatory mediators Explanation: The given scenario is an example of anaphylaxis following shrimp intake, which is an example of a type 1 hypersensitivity reaction. Type 1 hypersensitivity reaction: Synonyms Immediate hypersensitivity Allergy Features Occurs in previously sensitised individuals to an antigen, where the antigen binds to IgE antibodies on mast cells Types Local Systemic

questions.question: Which of the following cytokines acts on B cells to stimulate class switching to IgE and promotes the development of additional Th2 cells in type I hypersensitivity reactions?
questions.explanation: Stimulates B cells to undergo class switching to IgE and promotes the expansion of Th2 cells IL-5 (Option B) Development and activation of eosinophils → Recruited to the site of allergen exposure → Release inflammatory mediators and enzymes → Tissue damage and inflammation IL-13 (Option C) Amplifies IgE production Acts on epithelial cells to stimulate mucus secretion IL-10 (Option D) Anti-inflammatory cytokine Inhibits cytokine production by Th1 cells and macrophages. Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 207

questions.question: A 45-year-old patient with a history of allergic asthma presents with worsening respiratory symptoms. The sputum sample shows the presence of Charcot-Leyden crystals. Which of the following is NOT typically associated with this phase of hypersensitivity reaction?

options.A: Recruitment of eosinophils to the site of inflammation by chemokines like eotaxin
options.B: Production of IL-5 by Th2 cells to activate eosinophils
options.C: Release of histamine and tryptase by eosinophils
options.D: Liberation of major basic protein and eosinophil cationic protein by activated eosinophils

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Release of histamine and tryptase by eosinophils Explanation: The given scenario suggests that the patient's presentation involves eosinophils, particularly the identification of Charcot-Leyden crystals (composed of galectin-10 protein) in the extracellular space, which is derived from eosinophils. (suggestive of delayed phase of type 1 HSR). Histamine and tryptase are preformed mediators released by mast cells during the early phase of Type I hypersensitivity (Option B) , not by eosinophils in the late phase. Early phase reaction Late phase reaction Onset Immediate (within minutes of allergen exposure). Delayed (several hours after exposure) and can last for days. Cells involved Mast cells, basophils. Eosinophils, T lymphocytes. Cellular events Activation of mast cells and basophils. Recruitment and activation of leukocytes, especially eosinophils. Mediators Histamine, leukotrienes (LTB4, LTC4, LTD4), prostaglandins (PGD2) and Platelet-activating factor (PAF). Cytokines (e.g., IL-4, IL-5, TNF), chemokines (e.g., eotaxin) Initiating event Exposure to allergen triggers cross-linking of IgE on mast cells/basophils. Recurrent inflammation, sustained by recruited leukocytes. Effect on tissues Vasodilation, increased vascular permeability, smooth muscle contraction. Sustained inflammation and tissue damage due to leukocyte infiltration. Clinical manifestations Allergic rhinitis (hay fever), urticaria (hives), Angioedema bronchoconstriction. Allergic asthma exacerbation, persistent inflammation, and tissue damage. Therapeutic Approach Antihistamines for symptomatic relief. Adrenaline in anaphylactic shock Broad-spectrum anti-inflammatory drugs (e.g., steroids) to suppress inflammation and prevent tissue damage.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an example of a Type I hypersensitivity reaction?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Graft rejection Explanation: Graft rejection is not an example of a type I hypersensitivity reaction. Acute graft rejection involves Type II and Type IV hypersensitivity reactions. Hyperacute graft rejection involves Type II hypersensitivity reactions. Chronic graft rejection involves Type IV hypersensitivity reactions. Examples of Type I hypersensitivity reactions: Allergic conditions include Allergic rhinitis, Allergic dermatitis, Allergic conjunctivitis, or Vernal Keratoconjunctivitis (Option B). Bronchial asthma Casoni test: Done for detection of Echinococcus granulosus (Hydatid cyst) (Option C) . Drug reactions P-K reactions (Option D) The PK reaction is a laboratory technique used to demonstrate type I hypersensitivity, which involves IgE antibodies and mast cell degranulation, often leading to immediate allergic reactions. Theobald Smith phenomenon.(Theobald Smith phenomenon is the term for the development of hypersensitivity to bacteria in animals after repeated injections) Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 208

questions.question: Which of the following diseases is not an example of a Type II hypersensitivity reaction?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Multiple sclerosis Explanation: Multiple sclerosis is an example of a type IV hypersensitivity reaction, not type II. Examples of Type II hypersensitivity reactions are: Mnemonic: My Blood Group Is Rh Positive My Myasthenia Gravis Blood Blood transfusion reaction Group Good pasture syndrome, Graves disease Is Immune hemolytic anaemia, Immune thrombocytopenic purpura R Rh incompatibility, Rheumatic fever H Hyperacute transplant rejection Positive Pemphigus (Bullous), Pernicious Anemia Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Pages 204-215

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding pernicious anaemia is incorrect? phagocytosis or cell lysis.

options.A: Natural Killer (NK) cells participate in Antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity.
options.B: Opsonisation involves IgG antibodies coating cells, enhancing phagocytosis via Fc receptors.
options.C: When antibodies deposit in intracellular tissues, the injury is due to inflammation and not
options.D: Myasthenia gravis is an example of antibody-mediated cell surface receptor dysfunction.

questions.explanation: inflammation and not phagocytosis or cell lysis. Correct Answer: C) When antibodies deposit in intracellular tissues, the injury is due to inflammation and not phagocytosis or cell lysis. Explanation: In pernicious anaemia, the type of hypersensitivity involved is Type II hypersensitivity, also known as antibody-mediated hypersensitivity. This type of hypersensitivity occurs when antibodies bind to antigens on host cells, leading to cell destruction or dysfunction. Mechanisms of Type II hypersensitivity Description Examples Opsonisation and Phagocytosis (Option B) IgG antibodies coat cells, helping phagocytes recognise circulating antigen-opsonin complexes through Fc receptors or complement activation, leading to phagocytosis. Autoimmune hemolytic anaemia Immune thrombocytopenic purpura Rh hemolytic disease of the newborn. Complement activation and inflammation (Option C) Antibody deposition in extracellular tissues triggers inflammation, not phagocytosis or cell lysis. The deposited antibodies activate the complement system, leading to the attraction of neutrophils and monocytes via their Fc receptors. Activated leukocytes release enzymes, resulting in tissue damage. Goodpasture syndrome Acute rheumatic fever Antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC) (Option A) Natural killer cells bind to antibody-antigen complexes, inducing apoptotic cell death. Pernicious anemia Insulin resistant diabetes Antibody-mediated cellular dysfunction (non-cytotoxic) (Option D) Antibodies physically impair or dysregulate cellular function by binding to cell surface receptors. This includes both activation (e.g., thyroid hormone receptor in Graves disease) and inhibition (e.g., acetylcholine receptor in Myasthenia gravis). Graves disease Myasthenia gravis Mechanisms of Type II hypersensitivity Description Examples Opsonisation and Phagocytosis (Option B) IgG antibodies coat cells, helping phagocytes recognise circulating antigen-opsonin complexes through Fc receptors or complement activation, leading to phagocytosis. Autoimmune hemolytic anaemia Immune thrombocytopenic purpura Rh hemolytic disease of the newborn. The deposited antibodies activate the complement system, leading to the attraction of neutrophils and monocytes via their Fc receptors. Activated leukocytes release enzymes, resulting in tissue damage. Pernicious anemia Insulin resistant diabetes Antibody-mediated cellular dysfunction (non-cytotoxic) (Option D) Antibodies physically impair or dysregulate cellular function by binding to cell surface receptors. This includes both activation (e.g., thyroid hormone receptor in Graves disease) and inhibition (e.g., acetylcholine receptor in Myasthenia gravis). Graves disease Myasthenia gravis Note: Myasthenia gravis and Graves disease are now classified as Type V hypersensitivity (Type V > Type II) Type V hypersensitivity reaction: Antibodies against cellular receptors. Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Pages 209, 210

questions.question: An 11-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with swelling in his face and legs, decreased urine output, and dark-colored urine. His parents reported that he had a sore throat about three weeks ago, which resolved without treatment. Urinalysis shows proteinuria and hematuria. Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is associated with this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Type III hypersensitivity Explanation: The given clinical scenario suggests Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN), a classic example of a Type III hypersensitivity reaction . PSGN is an immune complex-mediated disease caused by the deposition of circulating immune complexes (composed of streptococcal antigens and antibodies) in the kidney glomeruli, leading to inflammation and damage. Examples of type III hypersensitivity: (mnemonic- SHARP) Serum sickness, Schick test, SLE (Hematological lesion) Henoch Schonlein purpura Arthus reaction Reactive arthritis Post-streptococcal Glomerulonephritis (PSGN), Polyarteritis Nodosa (PAN) Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Pages 210-212

questions.question: Which of the following is typically associated with localized immune-complex mediated hypersensitivity?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Arthus reaction Explanation: The presentation from the given clinical scenario suggests localized immune-complex mediated hypersensitivity or Type III hypersensitivity reaction. The “Arthus reaction” is localized tissue necrosis caused by acute immune complex vasculitis, often occurring in the skin. It occurs when pre-existing antibodies (IgG) interact with antigens locally injected into the skin or other tissues, leading to complement activation, inflammation, and tissue damage. This reaction is typically seen in response to repeated exposure to certain antigens (e.g., vaccines) and results in a localised inflammatory response such as localised swelling, redness, pain, and tissue destruction. Systemic type III hypersensitivity Localised type III hypersensitivity Involves the widespread formation of immune complexes in circulation and can deposit in various tissues and organs throughout the body, including the kidneys (leading to glomerulonephritis), joints, skin, blood vessels, and other sites. (e.g., in chronic infections or autoimmune diseases). Immune complexes are deposited at specific sites of antigen exposure, such as the skin (as in the Arthus reaction) or joint spaces, leading to local inflammation (localized swelling, redness, pain) and tissue damage. Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Pages 210- 212

questions.question: A 40-year-old man presents with jaundice and fatigue, recently diagnosed with hepatitis B infection. Further investigation reveals abnormal liver function tests, indicating hepatic injury. Which of the following statements regarding the mechanisms of hypersensitivity involved in this case is true?

options.A: CD8+ T cells differentiate into Th1 and Th17 cells upon antigen exposure
options.B: CD4+ T cells differentiate into Th2 cells upon exposure to antigen
options.C: Cytotoxic T-lymphocytes (CTLs) directly kill virus-infected cells via the Fas-Fas ligand pathway
options.D: Perforin-granzyme-dependent killing is a mechanism employed by CD4+ T cells

questions.explanation: ligand pathway Correct Answer: C) Cytotoxic T-lymphocytes (CTLs) directly kill virus-infected cells via the Fas- Fas ligand pathway. Explanation: The type of hypersensitivity involved in hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection is Type IV. Mechanisms of Type IV hypersensitivity Description Examples Cytokine-mediated inflammation (mediated by CD4+ T cells) CD4+ T cells recognise protein antigens presented by APCs and differentiate into Th1 and Th17 cells (Options A and B ruled out) . Th1 cells secrete cytokines like IFN- γ , activating macrophages to cause tissue damage and fibrosis. Th17 cells produce IL-17 to recruit neutrophils, promoting inflammation. Tuberculin test (a classic example of delayed-type hypersensitivity) Granulomas Contact dermatitis Rheumatoid arthritis Multiple sclerosis IBD Psoriasis T cell-mediated cytotoxicity (mediated by CD8+ T cells) Cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CTLs) directly kill antigen-bearing target cells, including tumour cells, virus-infected cells, and allogeneic tissue, during graft rejection. CTLs use perforin-granzyme-dependent killing (Option D ruled out) and Fas-Fas ligand-dependent killing mechanisms to induce apoptosis in target cells. (Option C) Type 1 DM Hepatic injury in HBV infection Graft vs host disease

questions.question: A 35-year-old woman presents with a history of persistent cough and unintentional weight loss. The physician suspects a TB infection and performs a tuberculin skin test. Which of the following is not an example of the type of hypersensitivity reaction associated with this test?

options.A: Contact dermatitis from poison ivy exposure.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Reactive arthritis. Explanation: The tuberculin skin test (TST) mentioned in the scenario represents Delayed type hypersensitivity (Type IV hypersensitivity). Reactive arthritis, on the other hand, shows Type III hypersensitivity. Examples of Type IV hypersensitivity reactions: Contact dermatitis from exposure to Urushiol from poison ivy or poison oak Detergent Artificial jewellery (Ni and Cd) Granuloma Mantoux test Lepromin test Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn’s disease) Rheumatoid arthritis (Type IV > Type III hypersensitivity) Multiple sclerosis Sarcoidosis Psoriasis Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Pages 213

questions.question: Which of the following statements accurately describes Type V hypersensitivity? reactions.

options.A: Antibodies bind to cell surface receptors, leading to altered cellular function
options.B: Immune complexes form and deposit in tissues, triggering localized inflammation and damage.
options.C: Antibodies target cell surface antigens, resulting in complement activation and cell destruction.
options.D: IgE antibodies mediate the release of histamine from mast cells, causing immediate allergic

questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) Antibodies bind to cell surface receptors, leading to altered cellular function normal function of those cells. The antibodies may mimic hormones or block receptor function Leads to altered cellular activity without direct destruction of the cells. It can cause overstimulation or inhibition of normal cellular functions. Graves' disease: Antibodies stimulate the thyroid hormone receptor, causing hyperthyroidism. Myasthenia gravis : Antibodies block acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction, leading to muscle weakness. IgE antibodies mediate the release of histamine from mast cells, causing immediate allergic reactions (Option B) is a hallmark of Type I hypersensitivity, involving immediate reactions and allergic responses mediated by IgE. Immune complexes form and deposit in tissues, triggering localized inflammation and damage (Option C) describes Type III hypersensitivity, which involves immune complex deposition leading to inflammation. Antibodies target cell surface antigens, resulting in complement activation and cell destruction (Option D) is characteristic of Type II hypersensitivity, where antibody binding leads to direct cell damage through complement activation. Reference: https://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/hypersensitivity-reactions#type-3 https://dermnetnz.org/topics/allergies-explained

questions.question: Which of the following sequences correctly describes the phases of pathogenesis in Type III hypersensitivity? → Inflammation and tissue injury → Deposition in blood vessels. → Formation of antibodies → Tissue injury and inflammation. → Deposition in tissues → Inflammation and tissue injury. → Immune complex formation → Activation of cytotoxic T cells.
questions.explanation: → Deposition in tissues → Inflammation and tissue injury. Correct answer: C) Formation of immune complexes → Deposition in tissues → Inflammation and tissue injury. Explanation: Phases of Type 3 hypersensitivity: 1. Formation of Immune Complexes : After introducing a protein antigen, antibodies are formed (typically within one week) and react with the antigen in circulation, creating antigen-antibody complexes. 2. Deposition of Immune Complexes : These complexes circulate and are deposited in blood vessels, particularly in organs like the kidneys and joints. Medium-sized complexes formed in slight antigen excess are most pathogenic. 3. Inflammation and Tissue Injury: Deposited immune complexes trigger acute inflammation about 10 days post-antigen exposure, leading to symptoms like fever, joint pain, and proteinuria. Complement activation contributes to tissue injury, with serum C3 levels potentially serving as a marker for disease activity. Histopathological lesions: Inflammation and necrotizing vasculitis (fibrinoid necrosis). Type 3 hypersensitivity (Mnemonic - T SHARP ): T ype II lepra reaction. S LE. S erum sickness. H enoch Schonlein Purpura. H ypersensitivity pneumonitis. A rthus reaction. R eactive Arthritis. P ost streptococcal glomerulonephritis. P olyarteritis nodosa. P arasitic diseases. Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Pages 211, 212
